apple.passage: Apple is a fruit that is widely consumed and enjoyed all over the world. It is a member of the Rosaceae family and is scientifically known as Malus domestica. Apples are grown on trees and are typically round or oval in shape, with a red, green, or yellow skin. The flesh of the apple is white or cream-colored and is juicy and sweet. Apples are one of the most popular fruits in the world, and they are grown in many different countries. The United States is the largest producer of apples, followed by China, Turkey, Poland, and Italy. Apples are grown in many different climates, from temperate to tropical regions. Apples are a good source of fiber, vitamin C, and antioxidants. They are also low in calories, making them a great snack for people who are trying to lose weight. Apples are also known to have many health benefits, including reducing the risk of heart disease, stroke, and certain types of cancer. There are many different varieties of apples, each with its own unique flavor and texture. Some of the most popular varieties include Granny Smith, Red Delicious, Golden Delicious, Gala, and Fuji. Apples can be eaten raw, cooked, or baked, and they are often used in desserts, such as apple pie and apple crisp. In addition to being a popular food, apples have also played an important role in mythology and folklore. In Greek mythology, the goddess of discord, Eris, threw a golden apple into a gathering of gods and goddesses, which sparked a competition that ultimately led to the Trojan War. In the story of Adam and Eve in the Bible, the apple is said to be the fruit that led to their expulsion from the Garden of Eden. Overall, apples are a delicious and nutritious fruit that has been enjoyed by people for thousands of years. Whether eaten raw or cooked, they are a versatile ingredient that can be used in a variety of dishes.

banana.passage: Bananas are a popular fruit that are widely consumed around the world. They are native to tropical regions of Southeast Asia, but are now grown in many other parts of the world, including Central and South America, Africa, and the Caribbean. Bananas are a good source of vitamins and minerals, and are also high in fiber. The banana plant is actually a type of herb, and the fruit is technically a berry. The plant grows up to 30 feet tall, and produces large, green leaves that can be up to 9 feet long. The fruit grows in clusters, and can be up to 12 inches long. Bananas are typically harvested when they are still green, and then ripen over time. There are many different varieties of bananas, each with their own unique flavor and texture. Some of the most popular varieties include Cavendish, which is the most commonly grown variety worldwide, and the smaller, sweeter Lady Finger banana. Bananas are a versatile fruit that can be eaten on their own, or used in a variety of recipes. They are often used in smoothies, baked goods, and as a topping for cereal or yogurt. Bananas can also be dried and used as a snack, or mashed and used as a natural sweetener in recipes. In addition to their culinary uses, bananas also have a number of health benefits. They are high in potassium, which is important for maintaining healthy blood pressure and heart function. Bananas are also a good source of vitamin C, vitamin B6, and dietary fiber. Overall, bananas are a delicious and nutritious fruit that are enjoyed by people all over the world. Whether eaten on their own or used in recipes, they are a versatile and healthy addition to any diet.

carrot.passage: The carrot (Daucus carota) is a root vegetable that is widely cultivated and consumed throughout the world. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which also includes parsley, fennel, and dill. Carrots are known for their bright orange color, although they can also be found in other colors such as purple, white, yellow, and red. Carrots are a rich source of vitamins and minerals, particularly vitamin A, which is important for maintaining healthy vision, skin, and immune function. They also contain significant amounts of vitamin K, potassium, and fiber. Carrots are low in calories and are often included in weight loss diets. Carrots can be eaten raw or cooked and are used in a variety of dishes, including salads, soups, stews, and casseroles. They can also be juiced or blended into smoothies. Carrots are often paired with other vegetables, such as celery and onions, to create a mirepoix, which is a base for many sauces and soups. Carrots are believed to have originated in Central Asia and were first cultivated for their medicinal properties. They were later introduced to Europe and North America, where they became a popular food crop. Today, China is the world's largest producer of carrots, followed by Uzbekistan, Russia, and the United States. Carrots are typically grown in well-drained soil and require regular watering. They can be planted in the spring or fall and take about 70-80 days to mature. Carrots can be harvested when they are about 1-2 inches in diameter, although some varieties can grow much larger. In addition to their culinary uses, carrots have also been used for medicinal purposes throughout history. They were believed to have healing properties for a variety of ailments, including digestive issues, respiratory problems, and skin conditions. While modern medicine has largely replaced the use of carrots for medicinal purposes, they are still valued for their nutritional benefits. Overall, carrots are a versatile and nutritious vegetable that can be enjoyed in a variety of ways. Whether eaten raw or cooked, they are a great addition to any diet and provide a range of health benefits.

chicken.passage: The chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is a domesticated fowl, a subspecies of the red junglefowl. As one of the most common and widespread domestic animals, with a population of more than 19 billion in 2011, there are more chickens in the world than any other bird or domesticated fowl. Humans keep chickens primarily as a source of food, consuming both their meat and their eggs. Chickens are believed to have been domesticated from the red junglefowl in Southeast Asia more than 10,000 years ago. They were first brought to Europe by the Romans, and later to the Americas by European explorers. Today, chickens are found all over the world, in a wide variety of breeds and colors. Chickens are omnivores, eating a diet that includes grains, insects, and small animals. They are social animals, living in groups called flocks, and have a complex social hierarchy. Roosters, or male chickens, are known for their distinctive crowing, which they use to establish their dominance over other males and to attract females. Chickens are also known for their ability to lay eggs, which are a rich source of protein and other nutrients. Hens, or female chickens, can lay up to 300 eggs per year, depending on the breed. Eggs are used in a wide variety of dishes, from breakfast omelets to baked goods. In addition to their role as a food source, chickens are also used for their feathers, which are used in clothing and other products, and for their manure, which is used as fertilizer. Chickens are also sometimes kept as pets, particularly in urban areas where space is limited. Despite their widespread use and popularity, chickens face a number of challenges, including disease, predation, and poor living conditions in some commercial operations. Animal welfare advocates have called for improved conditions for chickens, including more space, better ventilation, and access to the outdoors. Overall, the chicken is a versatile and important domestic animal, providing food, feathers, and fertilizer to people all over the world.

fish.passage: Fish are aquatic animals that are found in almost every body of water on Earth, from the smallest streams to the deepest oceans. They are a diverse group of animals, with over 34,000 species identified so far. Fish are cold-blooded, meaning that their body temperature is regulated by the temperature of the water around them. They breathe through gills, which extract oxygen from the water, and most fish have scales that protect their skin and help them swim. Fish come in many different shapes and sizes, from tiny minnows to massive whale sharks. They can be found in freshwater or saltwater, and some species can even survive in both. Fish play an important role in the ecosystem, serving as both predator and prey. They are a major food source for humans and other animals, and many species are also kept as pets. Fish are divided into two main groups: bony fish and cartilaginous fish. Bony fish, which make up the majority of fish species, have a skeleton made of bone and a swim bladder that helps them control their buoyancy. Cartilaginous fish, such as sharks and rays, have a skeleton made of cartilage and do not have a swim bladder. Fish have a variety of adaptations that help them survive in their aquatic environments. Some fish have specialized organs that allow them to produce and detect electric fields, which they use to navigate and communicate with other fish. Others have evolved the ability to change color or shape to blend in with their surroundings or to attract mates. Despite their importance, many fish populations are threatened by overfishing, pollution, and habitat destruction. Conservation efforts are underway to protect these important animals and their habitats.

qae_pairs.explanation: Fish are found in almost every body of water on Earth, as stated in the passage.

grapefruit.passage: Grapefruit is a subtropical citrus fruit that is known for its tangy and slightly bitter taste. It is believed to have originated in Barbados in the 18th century as a hybrid between the pomelo and the sweet orange. The fruit is round or oblong in shape and can range in color from yellow to pink or red. The flesh of the grapefruit is segmented and juicy, with a sour and slightly sweet flavor. Grapefruit is a rich source of vitamins and minerals, including vitamin C, vitamin A, potassium, and fiber. It is also low in calories and has been shown to have numerous health benefits. Studies have suggested that grapefruit may help lower cholesterol levels, reduce the risk of heart disease, and aid in weight loss. There are several different varieties of grapefruit, including white, pink, and red. White grapefruit is the most common variety and has a yellowish-white flesh. Pink grapefruit has a pinkish-red flesh and is slightly sweeter than white grapefruit. Red grapefruit is the sweetest variety and has a deep red flesh. Grapefruit can be eaten on its own or used in a variety of recipes, including salads, smoothies, and cocktails. It is also commonly used in the production of grapefruit juice, which is a popular breakfast beverage. Despite its many health benefits, grapefruit can interact with certain medications, including some cholesterol-lowering drugs and antidepressants. It is important to consult with a healthcare provider before consuming grapefruit or grapefruit juice if you are taking any medications. Overall, grapefruit is a delicious and nutritious fruit that can be enjoyed in a variety of ways. Its unique flavor and health benefits make it a popular choice for those looking to improve their diet and overall health.

hamburger.passage: A hamburger, also known as a burger, is a sandwich consisting of one or more cooked patties of ground meat, usually beef, placed inside a sliced bread roll or bun. The patty may be pan-fried, grilled, smoked or flame-broiled. Hamburgers are often served with cheese, lettuce, tomato, onion, pickles, bacon, or chiles; condiments such as ketchup, mustard, mayonnaise, relish, or "special sauce"; and are frequently placed on sesame seed buns. A hamburger topped with cheese is called a cheeseburger. The term "burger" can also be applied to the meat patty on its own, especially in the UK where the term "patty" is rarely used, or the term can even refer simply to ground beef. The term may be prefixed with the type of meat or meat substitute used, as in "turkey burger", "bison burger", or "veggie burger". The hamburger originated in the late 19th or early 20th century. The modern hamburger was a product of the culinary needs of a society rapidly changing due to industrialization, the emergence of the working class and middle class and the demand for mass-produced, affordable food that could be consumed outside of the home. The hamburger became popular in the United States and Canada, and has become a staple in the fast food industry. The world's largest hamburger weighed 2,014 pounds (914 kg) and was cooked in 2012 in Carlton, Minnesota, US. The hamburger was 10 feet (3.05 m) in diameter and took over 15 hours to cook. The largest commercially available hamburger weighed 777 pounds (352 kg) and was prepared by Black Bear Casino Resort in Carlton, Minnesota, US in 2017. Hamburgers are a popular food item in fast food restaurants, diners, and bars. They are also a common menu item in many restaurants that serve American cuisine. Hamburgers have become a symbol of American culture and are often associated with backyard barbecues, Fourth of July celebrations, and fast food chains such as McDonald's, Burger King, and Wendy's.

ice cream.passage: Ice cream is a sweetened frozen food typically eaten as a snack or dessert. It is usually made from dairy products, such as milk and cream, and often combined with fruits or other flavorings. Ice cream can be served in a variety of forms, including cones, cups, and bars. The origins of ice cream can be traced back to ancient China, where a mixture of milk and rice was frozen in snow. The first recorded instance of ice cream being served in Europe was in the 16th century, when Italian chefs created a frozen dessert made from cream, sugar, and fruit. In the United States, ice cream became popular in the late 19th century, with the invention of the hand-cranked ice cream maker. This device allowed people to make ice cream at home, and it quickly became a staple of American cuisine. Today, ice cream is enjoyed all over the world, with a wide variety of flavors and styles available. Some popular flavors include vanilla, chocolate, strawberry, and mint chocolate chip. Ice cream can also be made with non-dairy ingredients, such as soy milk or coconut milk, for those who are lactose intolerant or vegan. In addition to being a delicious treat, ice cream has also been the subject of scientific research. Scientists have studied the properties of ice cream, including its texture, melting rate, and ability to resist melting. This research has led to the development of new types of ice cream, such as low-fat and low-sugar varieties. Overall, ice cream is a beloved dessert that has been enjoyed for centuries. Whether you prefer classic flavors or more exotic varieties, there is an ice cream out there for everyone to enjoy.

jelly.passage: Jelly is a sweet, clear, and semi-solid food that is made by boiling fruit juice, sugar, and pectin together. Pectin is a natural substance found in fruits that helps the jelly to set. The mixture is then poured into jars and allowed to cool and set. Jelly is often served as a spread on toast, biscuits, or scones, and is a popular ingredient in desserts and baked goods. Jelly can be made from a variety of fruits, including strawberries, raspberries, blackberries, blueberries, and grapes. Each fruit has its own unique flavor and texture, which can be enhanced by adding spices or other ingredients. For example, cinnamon and cloves can be added to apple jelly, while ginger and lemon can be added to peach jelly. Jelly is a popular food in many cultures around the world. In the United States, grape jelly is a common ingredient in peanut butter and jelly sandwiches, while in the United Kingdom, jelly is often served with cream as part of a traditional afternoon tea. In France, jelly is known as confiture, and is often served with croissants or other pastries. Jelly can also be used as a glaze for meats, such as ham or pork. The sweet and tangy flavor of the jelly complements the savory flavor of the meat, creating a delicious and unique dish. Jelly can also be used as a filling for cakes and pastries, or as a topping for ice cream or yogurt. Jelly is a low-fat and low-calorie food, making it a popular choice for those who are watching their weight. However, it is important to note that jelly is high in sugar, so it should be consumed in moderation. Additionally, some commercial jellies may contain artificial colors and flavors, so it is important to read the label before purchasing. Overall, jelly is a versatile and delicious food that can be enjoyed in a variety of ways. Whether you prefer it on toast, in a sandwich, or as a glaze for meat, jelly is sure to add a sweet and flavorful touch to any meal.

China..passage: China, officially the People's Republic of China, is a country in East Asia. It is the world's most populous country, with a population of around 1.4 billion. Covering approximately 9.6 million square kilometers, it is the world's third or fourth-largest country by area. The country is officially divided into 23 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. China emerged as one of the world's earliest civilizations, in the fertile basin of the Yellow River in the North China Plain. For millennia, China's political system was based on hereditary monarchies, or dynasties, beginning with the semi-legendary Xia dynasty in 21st century BCE. Since then, China has expanded, fractured, and re-unified numerous times. In the 3rd century BCE, the Qin reunited core China and established the first Chinese empire. The succeeding Han dynasty, which ruled from 206 BCE until 220 CE, saw some of the most advanced technology at that time, including papermaking and the compass, along with agricultural and medical improvements. The invention of gunpowder and movable type in the Tang dynasty (618–907) and Northern Song Dynasty (960–1127) completed the Four Great Inventions. Tang culture spread widely in Asia, as the new Silk Route brought traders to as far as Mesopotamia and the Horn of Africa. The Qing dynasty, which lasted from 1644 until 1912, was the last imperial dynasty of China. In the late 19th century, the Qing dynasty was overthrown following the Boxer Rebellion, which was itself crushed by an international alliance led by the Eight-Nation Alliance. The establishment of the Republic of China in 1912 led to the Chinese Civil War and the division of China into the two political entities of the PRC and the ROC. The PRC is a one-party state governed by the Communist Party of China, with its seat of government in the capital city of Beijing. It exercises jurisdiction over 22 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. The PRC also claims Taiwan – which is controlled by the ROC – as its 23rd province, a claim controversial due to the complex political status of Taiwan and the unresolved Chinese Civil War.

Gallus gallus domesticus..passage: Gallus gallus domesticus, commonly known as the domestic chicken or simply chicken, is a type of domesticated fowl, a subspecies of the red junglefowl. It is one of the most common and widespread domestic animals, with a population of more than 19 billion as of 2011. Humans keep chickens primarily as a source of food, consuming both their meat and their eggs. The traditional poultry farming view of the domestication of the chicken is stated in Encyclopædia Britannica (2007): "Humans first domesticated chickens of Indian origin for the purpose of cockfighting in Asia, Africa, and Europe. Very little formal attention was given to egg or meat production... " Recent genetic studies have pointed to multiple maternal origins in Southeast, East, and South Asia, but with the clade found in the Americas, Europe, the Middle East and Africa originating in the Indian subcontinent. From India, the domesticated chicken was imported to Lydia in western Asia Minor, and to Greece by the fifth century BC.

Earth..passage: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life. According to radiometric dating and other sources of evidence, Earth formed over 4.5 billion years ago. Earth's gravity interacts with other objects in space, especially the Sun and the Moon, which is Earth's only natural satellite. Earth orbits around the Sun in 365.256 solar days, a period known as an Earth year. During this time, Earth rotates about its axis about 366.256 times. Earth's axis of rotation is tilted with respect to its orbital plane, producing seasons on Earth. The gravitational interaction between Earth and the Moon causes ocean tides, stabilizes Earth's orientation on its axis, and gradually slows its rotation. Earth's atmosphere consists mostly of nitrogen and oxygen, with small amounts of water vapor, carbon dioxide, and other gases. The atmospheric pressure varies at different layers and is about 1 atm at sea level. Earth's biosphere has significantly altered its atmosphere, oceans, and other abiotic factors, enabling the proliferation of aerobic organisms as well as the formation of the ozone layer which, together with Earth's magnetic field, blocks harmful solar radiation, permitting life on land. The physical properties of the Earth, as well as its geological history and orbit, have allowed life to persist.

Barbados..passage: Barbados is an island country in the Lesser Antilles of the West Indies, in the Caribbean region of North America. It is 34 kilometres (21 miles) in length and up to 23 km (14 mi) in width, covering an area of 432 km2 (167 sq mi). It is situated in the western area of the North Atlantic and 100 km (62 mi) east of the Windward Islands and the Caribbean Sea;[9] therein, Barbados is east of the Windwards, part of the Lesser Antilles, roughly at 13°N of the equator. It is about 168 km (104 mi) east of both the countries of Saint Lucia and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines and 400 km (250 mi) north-east of Trinidad and Tobago. Barbados is outside the principal Atlantic hurricane belt. Its capital and largest city is Bridgetown. Inhabited by Kalinago people since the 13th century, and prior to that by other Amerindians, Barbados was visited by Spanish navigators in the late 15th century and claimed for the Spanish Crown. It first appeared in a Spanish map in 1511. The Portuguese visited the island in 1536, but they left it unclaimed, with their only remnants being an introduction of wild hogs for a good supply of meat whenever the island was visited. An English ship, the Olive Blossom, arrived in Barbados in 1625; its men took possession of it in the name of King James I. In 1627, the first permanent settlers arrived from England, and it became an English and later British colony.

Burger King..passage: Burger King is an American multinational chain of hamburger fast food restaurants. Headquartered in Miami-Dade County, Florida, the company was founded in 1953 as Insta-Burger King, a Jacksonville, Florida-based restaurant chain. After Insta-Burger King ran into financial difficulties in 1954, its two Miami-based franchisees David Edgerton and James McLamore purchased the company and renamed it "Burger King". Over the next half-century, the company would change hands four times, with its third set of owners, a partnership of TPG Capital, Bain Capital, and Goldman Sachs Capital Partners, taking it public in 2002. In late 2010, 3G Capital of Brazil acquired a majority stake in the company, in a deal valued at US$3.26 billion. The new owners promptly initiated a restructuring of the company to reverse its fortunes. 3G, along with partner Berkshire Hathaway, eventually merged the company with Canadian-based doughnut chain Tim Hortons, under the auspices of a new Canadian-based parent company named Restaurant Brands International.

Europe..passage: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere and mostly in the Eastern Hemisphere. It is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. It comprises the westernmost part of Eurasia. Since around 1850, Europe is most commonly considered to be separated from Asia by the watershed divides of the Ural and Caucasus Mountains, the Ural River, the Caspian and Black Seas, and the waterways of the Turkish Straits. Although the term "continent" implies physical geography, the land border is somewhat arbitrary and has moved since its first conception in classical antiquity. The division of Eurasia into two continents reflects East-West cultural, linguistic, and ethnic differences, some of which vary on a spectrum rather than with a sharp dividing line. The border does not follow political boundaries, with Turkey, Russia, and Kazakhstan being transcontinental countries. Europe covers about 10,180,000 square kilometres (3,930,000 sq mi), or 2% of the Earth's surface (6.8% of land area), making it the second smallest continent (using the seven-continent model). Politically, Europe is divided into about fifty sovereign states of which the Russian Federation is the largest and most populous, spanning 39% of the continent and comprising 15% of its population. Europe had a total population of about 741 million (about 11% of the world population) as of 2018.

Centuries..passage: Centuries are units of time that are equal to 100 years. They are commonly used to measure the passage of time in human history, particularly in the study of art, literature, and culture. The concept of centuries is based on the Gregorian calendar, which was introduced by Pope Gregory XIII in 1582. This calendar replaced the Julian calendar, which had been in use since 45 BCE. The Gregorian calendar is a solar calendar, meaning that it is based on the Earth's orbit around the sun. It is divided into 12 months, each of which has either 30 or 31 days, except for February, which has 28 days in a common year and 29 days in a leap year. The first century CE began on January 1, 1 CE, and ended on December 31, 100 CE. The second century began on January 1, 101 CE, and ended on December 31, 200 CE, and so on. The current century, the 21st century, began on January 1, 2001, and will end on December 31, 2100.

Pectin..passage: Pectin is a structural heteropolysaccharide contained in the primary cell walls of terrestrial plants. It was first isolated and described in 1825 by Henri Braconnot. It is produced commercially as a white to light brown powder, mainly extracted from citrus fruits, and is used in food as a gelling agent, particularly in jams and jellies. It is also used in fillings, medicines, sweets, as a stabilizer in fruit juices and milk drinks, and as a source of dietary fiber. Pectin is a complex mixture of polysaccharides, mainly composed of galacturonic acid, with smaller amounts of other sugars such as rhamnose, arabinose, and galactose. The degree of esterification (DE) of pectin is an important factor in determining its gelling properties. Pectin with a high DE forms a weak gel, whereas pectin with a low DE forms a strong gel. Pectin is also used in molecular gastronomy as a thickening agent.

qae_pairs.explanation: The scientist who first isolated and described Pectins in 1825 was Henri Braconnot, as stated in the passage.
